# Task

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.



# Data

timezone_bumper(DateTime(2023, 4, 10, 12, 0),3)

Here is a Julia solution:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date)
    throw(ArgumentError("This function works only with DateTime types."))
end
```

You can call the function `timezone_bumper()` with a DateTime type and an optional bump argument (defaults to +3 hours). If you pass a Date instead, it will throw an error. This solution uses the built-in Dates library for date and time operations in Julia.
